awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis and Chemical Synthesis Programs of the NSF Division of Chemistry are supporting the research of Professor Steven T. Diver of the State University of New York at Buffalo. Professor Diver is studying the development of new catalysts, the ways they react, and the use of new methods for the synthesis of biologically-active compounds such as products derived from nature (natural products). This project takes a new approach to catalysis inspired by enzymes. In organic synthesis, catalysts are used to speed up reactions and make new chemical transformations possible. In Nature, enzymes are protein-based catalysts that orient their reactive groups in three-dimensional space to facilitate a chemical reaction. Enzymes have great specificity in the starting materials they bind with as they create a microenvironment that recognizes and facilitates chemical reactions. In this project, Dr. Diver is positioning a well-known metal binding group inside a large, synthetic, molecular cavity. The cavity creates a unique chemical and spatial environment for reactions catalyzed by the bound metal. The environment surrounding the reactive metal center is being used to differentiate molecules based on their size. This approach is providing a way to gain selectivity over previously unselective chemical reactions. This project is educating scientists in a diverse and intellectually-stimulating research environment. Professor Diver is implementing a new teacher certification program designed to give new Ph.D. graduates experience in teaching that will improve outcomes at small colleges and community colleges, where quality teachers are needed. Additional outreach efforts at the elementary level include developing scientific awareness of molecules and their functions and uses in society.

A major challenge in organic synthesis is the ability to differentiate reactivity between two of the same functional group. This award is addressing this problem in the context of cross alkene metathesis and other reactions through the development of new catalysts located inside macrocyclic cavities. The orientation and metal binding is provided by an N-heterocyclic carbene ligand (NHC), which is incorporated into the macrocycle. NHC ligands are highly versatile and found in many different transition metal complexes, including ruthenium (Ru) catalysts for alkene metathesis. Though a widely used and important reaction, there are limitations in cross metathesis between two alkenes that have similar reactivity. This project is utilizing size control, possible with enzymes, to differentiate alkenes - a new approach to the problem of selective cross alkene metathesis. The principle of size-selectivity is also being applied to other metal-catalyzed reactions such as palladium-catalyzed cross couplings, where size control can prevent side reactions. Cross coupling and alkene metathesis are two of the most important reactions for synthesizing new molecules such as medicinal compounds, molecular probes, natural products, and materials. Ultimately, improvements in catalysis make advanced chemical manufacturing cheaper, more predictable, and more efficient. In addition to these scientific broader impacts, this project facilitates the recruitment of students of diverse backgrounds, encourages science literacy in elementary schoolers, and enables a chemistry-specific teacher training program designed to improve preparedness and placement of new Ph.D graduates into college teaching careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
?Size Selective Macrocyclic Catalysts? CHE-1900392

Project Outcomes

Intellectual Merits       Catalysis is vital to efficiency and selectivity in organic synthesis. New catalysts can be used to address problems in catalysis such as substrate selectivity. Small molecule, molecular catalysts often lack the ability to discern between subtle differences in substrates, such as different degree of substitution or different functional groups, especially when these are remote from the reactive part of the molecule. In this regard, Nature has designed enzymes as catalysts which are highly proficient in distinguishing between very similar substrates due to different chirality or differences in molecular structure. Yet enzymes lack the versatility of organic catalysts especially in terms of promoting metal catalyzed cross coupling reactions. A new design approach to catalysts could address this limitation of modern catalysis by utilizing macrocyclic structures to define a cavity in which the catalyzed reaction can take place. The size, dimension and chirality of the cavity could impart selectivity in the reaction. This concept has the potential to change the way that human made organic catalysts work, and could significantly improve efficiency in synthesis by allowing selective, late stage reactions which would minimize the use of protecting groups. Though synthesis of most molecules is considered possible in this modern age, efficient organic synthesis is still difficult and requires new tools in catalysis to streamline synthesis. Improved synthetic efficiency is likely to positively impact many scientific fields that benefit from organic synthesis, such as drug development, medicinal chemistry and synthesis of new functional materials, to name a few. 

            This NSF project resulted in the synthesis of two different macrocyclic catalysts that catalyzed selective alkene metathesis reactions. This project focused on the Nobel Prize winning alkene metathesis reaction developed by Professors Grubbs, Schrock and Chauvin. Alkene metathesis is widely used because it is a chemoselective, catalytic C-C bond forming reaction. Ideally, these reactions use equimolar amounts of reactants (atom economy), but that is seldom achieved in practice. Despite its widespread use, alkene metathesis falters in bringing about selective cross coupling of alkenes that have similar electronic properties, and existing catalysts cannot distinguish between remote structural features in the reactant molecules. We therefore created macrocyclic catalysts that could show selectivity in these reactions and allow atom economical alkene metathesis cross coupling. The first catalyst was synthesized in a one step Suzuki coupling/macrocyclization, which resulted in assembly of the macrocyclic, cage like structure. Using the versatile N-heterocyclic carbene ligand, we installed a Ru carbene and demonstrated size selective metathesis reactions. Structural studies showed the cavity may be too restricted and could benefit from enlargement or further rigidification. In the second case, we designed a rigidified N-heterocyclic carbene containing macrocycle and installed the Ru carbene. This structure proved surprising: two rotamers were isolated, one with the Ru protruding outside the cavity and one rotamer with the Ru inside the cavity. These catalysts showed large differences in reactivity in alkene metathesis applications. Last, the macrocyclic azolium salts yield nucleophilic catalysts that also displayed selectivity in intramolecular Michael-Stetter reactions.

Broader Impacts         Broader impacts of this project included the training of future scientists, including individuals from underrepresented groups. The key graduate students who participated have gone on to jobs in the pharmaceutical industry and the undergraduates have gone on to chemistry Ph.D programs. The new approach to selective catalysis is likely to shorten synthesis routes to accelerate the synthesis of molecules for chemical biology and medicinal chemistry studies, thereby speeding up the drug discovery process in the pharmaceutical industry. This is expected to decrease costs of pharmaceuticals, which could have a positive economic impact. Ability of catalysts to select remote steric attributes will allow syntheses that allow multiple functional groups to be present at once, changing the way that organic synthesis is planned and executed. 

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2023
Modified by: Steven T Diver
